project.byline: Story by Lauren Caruba | Photos by Carolyn Van Houten | San Antonio Express-News
project.title: Life in transition
project.byline_picker: {"authors":[{"id":"custom","profile_name":"Story by Lauren Caruba | Photos by Carolyn Van Houten | San Antonio Express-News","has_avatar":false,"is_atavist":false,"url":null,"type":"custom"}]}

sections.body:
Lauryn Farris took a seat at the end of the auburn table, where hundreds of others had sat before her. It was a quarter past 2 o’clock in the morning, and instead of sleeping at home in San Antonio, she was in the depths of the Texas Capitol, waiting to say her piece. Farris had waited for 18 hours, listening as hundreds of people testified for — and, overwhelmingly, against — a Senate “bathroom bill.”


There was a pastor, also from San Antonio, who said that gender, like race, was part of life’s “immutables.” There was a contingent of unhappy families from Dripping Springs, where the school district had allowed a transgender girl to use the girls’ restroom. There were numerous transgender Texans and their families, who publicly shared intimate details of their lives as they asked lawmakers to vote against the bill. And then there was Farris, a 60-year-old transgender activist from San Antonio, whose turn it finally was to sit before the Senate committee.


By this hour, no one seemed to be listening. It felt futile, like the decision had already been made about Senate Bill 6, which would require bathroom use in public schools and government buildings align with the gender listed on a person’s birth certificate. But Farris would speak anyways, at least for the record’s sake. After all, this wasn’t just about her — in her mind, it was about a national fight for the rights of all trans people, including the transgender girl she adopted from the foster care system. She looked down at her notes and cleared her throat.


“I am a Christian. I am the Alamo Region coordinator for the Transgender Education Network of Texas, a grandmother, a biological parent, an adoptive parent, and a lifelong allergy sufferer — my sympathies are with you,” Farris said, eliciting laughter for her reference to Sen. Joan Huffman’s congestion that evening. “And those identities identify me much more than the fact that I am also a transgender woman.” If you wanted, she added, you could call her a father too, but at her core she was just a parent.


By the time Farris got home, the panel had voted 8-1 in favor of the bill. The next month, in an astoundingly similar scene, Farris would testify once again after 2 a.m., against another bathroom bill, this time in the House.


Long days and late nights have become the norm for Farris and other transgender advocates in Texas, where the debate over gender identity has taken center stage. This session, lawmakers filed two dozen bills that advocates fear would harm the LGBTQ community, including a pair of bills that would legislate bathroom use for transgender people. In some cases, questions over how to define gender has even bled into unrelated legislation, including one that would regulate ride-hailing companies. Lawmakers and proponents of the bathroom bills argue the legislation will protect the privacy and safety of women and children. But in marathon hearings that extended into the early morning hours, hundreds of transgender people and their families pleaded with lawmakers to not discriminate against them.


Over the past several years, increased visibility for transgender people in pop culture, media and politics has been coupled with a steep rise in anti-LGBTQ legislation nationwide, advocates say. To those fighting against these bills, what happened in North Carolina after the passage and repeal of a bathroom bill there, and what is happening now in Texas, represents the next frontier for advancing civil rights.


For transgender Texans, the political vitriol only magnifies the personal challenges many already face. Transgender people must navigate an uncertain landscape as they seek acceptance from family, friends, co-workers. Some are bullied. Others fear for their physical safety, including — and at times, especially — when they walk into bathrooms. About 40 percent of trans individuals have a history of suicide attempts, and about the same proportion of homeless youth identify as LGBT. To transition, they must overcome legal and medical barriers, both of which can be costly or even prohibitive for those who are low-income. Most of all, they face the difficult task of living alongside those who still believe they have chosen to be this way.


After months of debate, hours upon hours of public testimony, countless press conferences and news stories, some transgender Texans have been left wondering if the state they call home, the state so intent on protecting women and children, is willing protect them, too. Even as the bathroom bills died, even if none of the other proposed legislation becomes law, the rhetoric has taken a toll on trans Texans. Advocates like Farris feel as if they are on the cusp of advancing society and the lives of transgender people, but some are asking themselves: How much will it hurt first?


“We made so much progress, and then you have just a few people in the world who for whatever reason have the beliefs they have,” Farris said. “So we just fight harder.”


***


Three years ago, when transgender actress Laverne Cox appeared on the cover of Time magazine, it seemed like a watershed moment for the transgender community. Here was a black transgender woman who was starring on a popular Netflix show, the first openly transgender person to grace the publication’s cover. Earlier that year, Amazon had debuted the show “Transparent,” which portrays a family as the father begins transitioning to a woman late in life. Then, in mid-2015, Caitlyn Jenner appeared on the cover of Vanity Fair, around the same time that the Supreme Court legalized same-sex marriage nationwide. Also that year, the Obama administration directed public schools to allow trans youth to use the bathrooms matching their gender identity. That directive would be rescinded when Donald Trump took office.


In a short time, public awareness of transgender people had come a long way. But while they enjoyed more visibility than ever, that did not necessarily translate into tangible legal protections. Federal discrimination laws still do not explicitly protect transgender people, though some courts have interpreted “sex” to include gender identity.


On top of that, the legislative attacks began. In 2016, HRC identified more than 200 anti-LGBT bills filed by state legislators nationwide, the most notorious of which was North Carolina’s House Bill 2. In a sweeping move, the law nullified all local nondiscrimination ordinances that provided protections for trans people using public restrooms. Over the next year, backlash to the law mounted as North Carolina drew the ire of businesses, professional sports leagues and the NCAA. Companies and celebrities boycotted the state. California legislators passed a law banning the use of state funds for travel to states with perceived anti-LGBTQ laws.


“After the success of marriage equality, anti-equality politicians were sort of looking for their next boogeyman — the next group of people that they could target and demonize in order to attract votes,” said Sarah McBride, national press secretary for the Human Rights Campaign and the first transgender person to address a major political convention.


Even as North Carolina continued to be the subject of wide criticism, Texas Republicans were ready to follow suit. In August 2016, Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick launched a petition asking Texans to “say ‘no’ to men in women’s restrooms.”


“Fort Worth ISD’s superintendent has unilaterally imposed a new policy allowing boys into girls’ restrooms and locker rooms. This goes against common sense and common decency,” the petition declared. Patrick soon delivered on his promise to make bathrooms a priority. In January, he unveiled Texas’ own bathroom bill, Senate Bill 6, by and large setting the tone for the session. Authored by Sen. Lois Kolkhorst of Brenham, the bill would limit bathroom use in public facilities, including public schools, by the gender listed on a person’s birth certificate. Public safety, he said, was paramount.


“We know we’re on the right side of the issue. We’re on the right side of history,” Patrick said at a news conference. “You can mark today as the day Texas is drawing a line in the sand and saying no.”


***


By early March, Texas lawmakers had filed two dozen bills that advocacy groups decried as discriminatory. The legislation largely fell into three main categories: religious refusal bills, which allowed denial of services based on “sincerely held religious beliefs”; so-called bathroom bills, which sought to legislate public accommodations; and bills that would invalidate nondiscrimination ordinances that provide local protections for the LGBTQ community.


A few didn’t, such as a bill that would allow the University Interscholastic League to disqualify student athletes using steroids, barring a “valid medical purpose.” The bill was filed after Mack Beggs, a 17-year-old trans boy from Euless, made national headlines in February when he won the state girls’ wrestling title after being prohibited from competing against boys. In May, the Senate gave the legislation preliminary approval.


On March 6, the day before the SB 6 hearing, hundreds of activists and allies from across the state gathered for Trans Texan Lobby Day, organized this year by Farris. Organizers had to move the meeting place to the Scottish Rite Theater when more than three times the number of expected participants signed up. A sheet of paper taped to the door of a multi-stall restroom declared it a gender neutral bathroom, to be used by men and women alike throughout the day. Trans people, their families, and local and national advocates gathered underneath a ceiling adorned with blue stars and ornate red trim as a series of speakers explained how to effectively lobby and offered words of encouragement.


“Texas is on the front lines for the battle for trans equality right now,” McBride told the room.


“SB 6 is not the only thing we need to watch,” said Lou Weaver, the transgender programs coordinator for Equality Texas, as he listed off other “bad” bills. “These are the scary ones, folks.”


During the orientation, the news broke that the U.S. Supreme Court had remanded the case of Gavin Grimm, a trans boy who sued his Virginia school board after it passed a policy that prevented him from using the boys’ restroom. What would happen next, American Civil Liberties Union legal and policy director Rebecca Robertson told the room, “is we go back to the Fourth Circuit and we keep fighting.”


Later in the day, as they wandered the hallways of the Capitol, families encountered aides who told them discrimination was “in the eye of the beholder.” Advocates who repeatedly asking to see Sen. Eddie Lucio Jr., the sole Senate Democrat to support the bathroom bill, found that when they left his offices, several Department of Public Safety officers arrived in their wake, reportedly in response to a noise complaint.


The next day, the energized mood of the lobby day shifted. Introducing SB 6 to a Senate panel, Kolkhorst insisted the bill was “nondiscriminatory,” that it would increase privacy in intimate spaces. “I’m proud to offer this bill to try to strike a balance, to protect, defend and give a dignified way as to how we move forward,” she said.


As the hearing stretched from 8 a.m. until 4 a.m. the next day, hundreds of people, many of them trans, testified and registered against the bill. Many were emotional as they explained how damaging such a law would be for trans people, especially trans children.


Only several dozen signaled their support.


***


Even as SB 6 enjoyed early momentum, it languished after passing the Senate in March. House Speaker Joe Straus repeatedly dismissed the issue as a low priority. But legislators seemed intent on passing some form of bathroom legislation, even if it meant compromising on the vision put forth by Patrick.


As SB 6 stalled, Rep. Ron Simmons promoted House Bill 2899 as a “compromise” to the other bill’s harsh language. Simmons’ bill would prohibit cities and school districts from protecting against discrimination in bathrooms, nullifying portions of nondiscrimination ordinances and policies. Gov. Greg Abbott, who had remained mostly mum on the issue, announced that he would be happy to see Simmons’ bill on his desk.


In April, trans people testified yet again into the early morning hours, in a hearing that did not adjourn until shortly before 5 a.m. The mother of a transgender girl from North Texas had her sleeping child slung across her back while she spoke. A transgender man from San Antonio explained the trauma he endured when he was raped in high school. Farris explained how she used to be so fearful of bathrooms, and how she didn’t want that for the next generation of transgender kids.


The House panel never voted on the bill, and it died in committee in early May. The other bathroom bill died too, as House leaders refused to assign it to a House committee. But lawmakers were not ready to give up. Simmons said he intends to push to include language from HB 2899 in amendments to other bills before the session ends on May 29.


Meanwhile, other bills advanced. Late at night on May 9, the House passed House Bill 3859, which would allow child welfare providers to turn away prospective adoptive or foster parents, including those who are LGBTQ, based on religious beliefs. The legislation did not occur in a vacuum — this year, the Department of Family and Protective Services removed language from the “bill of rights” for foster care children that ensures fair treatment regardless of gender identity and sexual orientation.


***


On the drive back to San Antonio after testifying against SB 6, Farris felt numb, drained. She had been deeply moved by the stories of other transgender Texans, but she was also amazed that some people could hate her, without even knowing her.


She and another transgender activist who rode back with her discussed how they could better educate people on trans issues, how they could change people’s minds.


Farris did not get home until after 5 a.m., three days after she had left home to spearhead the lobby day.


At 7:30 a.m., Farris picked up the phone and got back to work.


lcaruba@express-news.net

project.subtitle: As four federal grants draw to a close on a historically neglected side of town, what do the numbers say about progress made -- or not made?
project.social_title: Promises to Keep: Have federal grants helped a neglected area of San Antonio?
project.title: Promises to keep

sections.title: By the numbers
sections.title_partial:
{{title}}

{{subtitle}}

sections.title: Building hope in a neglected neighborhood
sections.body:
Paula Mabry peered into a vacant apartment one recent afternoon at East Meadows, a sprawling development nearing the end of construction on the East Side, her mother Lynnetta Louden standing behind her. Across the street, workers in hardhats tromped about.


The women waltzed into the empty living room and commenced to marvel. Even though everything was coated in a fine film of dust, the amenities stood out: Spacious rooms. Tall windows that let in golden light. A room with a washer and dryer. Kitchen countertops that looked like real granite.


“Get a load of that backsplash,” Louden said, noting an ornate plaster design above the sink.


The women were here to see if Louden, 67, a retired sales coordinator, and her two great-grandchildren might find a home at East Meadows. Louden, who lived in Austin most of her life but grew up on the East Side, retired two years ago and lives not far away from the new building. She’d “heard great things” about what was happening in the neighborhood.


Those “great things” include the creation of East Meadows, the first phase of a $100 million, 400-unit “mixed-income” residential development that is the most ambitious attempt by the San Antonio Housing Authority to fight concentrated poverty. SAHA has spent government funds before to create upscale-looking homes on the historically neglected East Side, developments that mix low-income and middle- and upper-income tenants on the theory that such diversity brings opportunity to blighted areas and helps lift up the most vulnerable residents.


But the East Meadows project, which includes a slew of street, sidewalk and other improvements in the surrounding neighborhood as well as social services to help disadvantaged tenants, takes things to a new level. It also sits in the middle of the so-called “footprint,” a 3.5-square-mile area on the East Side where several federal grants overlap and seek to transform the lives of 18,000 residents with a raft of poverty-fighting measures, from increasing access to early education and improving schools to strengthening families and providing adult workforce training.


East Meadows got off the ground in 2012, when the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development gave a $29.7 million Choice grant to SAHA to tear down Wheatley Courts, a derelict, 1940s-era housing project, and build in its place the 215-unit complex, an undertaking so modern it would be at home in any affluent North Side neighborhood. That same year, nearly $1 million in grants was awarded to bring down a high crime rate and increase public safety.


The year before, the U.S. Department of Education gave a $23.7 million Promise grant to the United Way of San Antonio and Bexar County to improve education and provide social services to the historically black but now Hispanic majority area, which has been rebranded as EastPoint by the city. The Promise grant sought to revitalize an area where the poverty rate is 40 percent or higher, double that of the city itself.


Among major cities, San Antonio has one of the worst rates of concentrated poverty and income segregation in the country, a topic recently explored in Worlds Apart, a special report by the Express-News.


The first phase of East Meadows, scheduled to be done in May, will be followed by two more phases designed for seniors, disabled people and additional families. The rest of the money for the project comes from $20 million in federal funds passed through the city, low-income housing tax credits and other money.


Since the grants were awarded, the city has kicked in another $45 million in 2012 bond money and $6 million in street maintenance funds in the Promise Zone, which includes $6.5 million in bond money for the creation of a $10 million linear park along Menger Creek, which also received $2.8 million in Bexar County flood control funds. An $8.1 million health clinic is in the works.


After President Obama in 2014 declared a larger, 22-square-mile area surrounding East Point as a Promise Zone, a designation that confers no money but gives groups an edge in applying for federal funds, another $17 million flowed to nonprofits, which set up charter schools, economic development programs and other projects.


The area surrounding East Meadows is clearly a neighborhood in transition. Boarded-up houses are in sight of sleek new lofts ready-made for millennials and young professionals, as private developers have poured more than $200 million into the gentrifying neighborhoods around the complex. More than 200 businesses have opened on the East and near-East Side since 2011, according to city records. A developer recently announced plans for an eight-acre, $150 million mixed-use project in Denver Heights, a gentrifying neighborhood just south of the Alamodome.


Whether all this money will truly turn around an area mired in intergenerational poverty and economic neglect won’t be known for years. Also unknown: what impact the Trump administration, which proposes to eliminate Choice grants like the one about to end here, will have.


On the afternoon when Mabry and her mother took their tour of East Meadows, Louden was dazzled by the transformation she saw around her. A graduate of Phillis Wheatley High School — now Wheatley Middle School — she said “nothing like this” existed in the days when she was coming up, gesturing outside to the lush landscaping and the flurry of development.


“There was bad stuff all around, drugs and the like,” she said. “And heaven forbid if you had a plumbing problem. It would be two weeks before the landlord got around to stopping by.”


Mabry was thrilled that her mother, who lives on a fixed income, might be able to snag a three-bedroom apartment for $650 a month, as opposed to the East Meadows market rate of $1,300.


Louden said she thought mixing low-income tenants with those with higher incomes means the complex has less chance of devolving through the years into squalor.


The more prosperous residents “will be cognizant about keeping things nice,” she said.

Mixed-income and more


At the East Meadows development, 75 percent of the units have subsidized rents — tenants pay a reduced amount tied to their income or receive government help. The rest are market-rate rents. Of the 205 families who had to relocate when Wheatley Courts was torn down, more than 60 are slated to return to East Meadows, a SAHA official said.


While the complex was in the midst of construction, some $3 million in Choice funds was used to hire a national nonprofit called Urban Strategies to provide services to former residents of Wheatley Courts displaced by the demolition of the old housing project. To date, staff have helped 143 former residents obtain subsidized vouchers to find other housing and take part in “self-sufficiency training” that includes everything from financial counseling and parenting classes to job training and adult education.


Those helped include residents who’ve decided to use their vouchers to move somewhere other than East Meadows, said Alicia Walter, Urban Strategies senior project manager.


New low-income tenants at East Meadows will be able to receive referrals to other social services and agencies, she said. Programs offered by Urban Strategies, such as GED classes, will be open to new tenants as well as the broader community if there aren’t enough former residents to fill all the spaces, she added. The program will end in August 2018.


Mike Etienne, director of EastPoint’s city office, said the Promise and Choice initiatives represent a break from urban renewal programs of the past, which tended to focus solely on brick-and-mortar projects or economic incubation. This new effort addresses “the needs of people” across the board.


“The challenges in high-poverty neighborhoods are interconnected, hence they require interconnected solutions,” he said.


More than 50 nonprofits and other organizations have been involved in EastPoint, from longtime stalwarts like the Ella Austin Community Center and big hitters like the YMCA and Boys & Girls Club San Antonio to smaller, mom-and-pop neighborhood operations.


In a program called Dual Generation, funded by the Annie E. Casey Foundation, Promise grant officials created partnerships with other agencies to provide high-quality early childhood education and after-school care to children 10 and under that simultaneously enables their parents to pursue free adult education and workforce training, mostly at a new job training center, dubbed the Eastside Education & Training Center, or EETC, on Dietrich Road.


A Promise-Zone-To-Work program, a combined partnership of Alamo Colleges, St. Philips, Workforce Solutions Alamo, Goodwill Industries and other entities, launched in fall 2015 and drew more than 2,000 job seekers and 150 employers to four events, Etienne said. More than 300 residents have earned certificates for “in-demand” jobs like certified nursing assistant, information technology, heavy equipment and welding. Of these graduates, more than 90 percent are Promise Zone residents, he said.


“The majority are employed, and of those who are working, 80 percent are working in their fields, primarily the medical field,” Etienne said. The percentage of East Side residents enrolled in nearby St. Philips swelled from 1 percent in 2012 to 10 percent in 2015, he added.


Critics and skeptics


As with any major undertaking like the Choice and Promise grants, especially one with so much money involved, there are those who take exception to the way things were done.


Brian Dillard, a cybersecurity consultant who was raised in Wheatley Courts, is one of some 60 graduates of the Neighborhood Leadership Academy, or NLA, a grassroots group formed to help sustain the progress of the Promise and Choice initiatives.


Dillard, 33, and a homeowner, currently heads the neighborhood association for Dignowity Hill, one of the hotbeds of gentrification on the rim of the footprint. A magnet for professionals, artists, hipsters and those willing to spend big bucks for historic homes, it even has its own millennial-ish moniker, Diggy Hill. Made up of weekly classes over four months, the NLA is an invaluable tool to train residents in how to work with the city to get things done, he said.


“It’s all about folks taking ownership in their communities and developing leaders,” he said.


But as volunteer entities, community groups like the NLA and neighborhood associations lack much in the way of permanence, he said. That function falls to city government, which ostensibly will be there as community engagement waxes and wanes.


In that regard, you can count Dillard among the skeptics. Early on, the District 2 council office convened quarterly meetings with the heads of the 16 neighborhood associations on the East Side. There hadn’t been one for almost a year, Dillard said in December.


Councilman Alan Warrick, when recently asked about the meetings, said one had just been held in January, and another in October 2016, although he couldn’t provide dates for other meetings held last year.


In any case, “we have an open door policy at our office, and last year we started (or reactivated) three new neighborhood associations,” Warrick said, noting that Dillard is campaigning for his opponent in the May City Council election. (For his part, Warrick said overall he was pleased with the EastPoint initiatives, but added that the EPN educational goals weren’t “ambitious” enough.)

Juan Garcia and his wife Barbara were pioneers in the renovation craze in Dignowity Hill, buying and rehabbing their home in 2007.

Garcia, a past president of the neighborhood association, said his main complaint is that all the energy and money was spent on the Choice grant area around East Meadows, not the larger Promise Zone or his neighborhood, which lies in the footprint. Yes, he acknowledged, some of his well-heeled neighbors can afford to drop tons of cash to refurbish their $400,000 houses.

Still, he said the streets and other infrastructure in his neighborhood are in sorry shape.

“Some places are in Third World conditions,” he said.

Etienne, ever the booster, said he is hopeful that EastPoint will serve as a “catalyst” for development in the wider zone.

Earlier this month, officials cut the ribbon on the $90,000 Gever Street Project, which improved sidewalks and other infrastructure around Washington Elementary. The project was part of the city’s $6 million allocation for streets, sidewalks and lighting in the area surrounding East Meadows, part of its $20 million federal funds commitment to the Choice initiative.


Still others worry that, over the years, East Meadows will devolve into yet another eyesore public housing project, no matter how nice the present amenities.

Rejane Frederick with the Center for American Progress, a nonpartisan think tank based in Washington, said that evaluating a multifaceted renewal program like EastPoint can be tricky: Which part was the most effective? Was it housing? Child care? Workforce training?


“And when you’re dealing with issues like generational poverty, it takes longer than five years to assess the collective impact,” she said. Going forward, officials should focus on what can be done at the local or state level, given the uncertainties about the Trump administration’s stance on spending federal money to help low-income people, she added.


Mayor Ivy Taylor, the former District 2 councilwoman who essentially got the ball rolling in 2009 when she convened a series of summits that looked at how the East Side might be saved after decades of neglect, said the federal grants have had “multiple positive effects,” and given residents hope that “things can change.”


For Mary Ellen Burns, senior vice president of grant administration for the United Way, “the genie is out of the bottle.”


“The residents have found their voices,” she said. “I don’t think there’s any going back. This is a new day. You just have to believe that.”


mstoeltje@express-news.net

GRAPHICS: BY THE NUMBERS

sections.byline: Stories by Melissa Fletcher Stoeltje | Photos by Lisa Krantz | Express-News staff
sections.title: Promises to keep
sections.byline_picker: {"authors":[{"id":"custom","profile_name":"Stories by Melissa Fletcher Stoeltje | Photos by Lisa Krantz | Express-News staff","has_avatar":false,"is_atavist":false,"url":null,"type":"custom"}]}
sections.body:
It’s Engineering Friday at Bowden Elementary School on the East Side, where students cluster around tables inside a second-grade classroom, their brows furrowed in concentration. Their task is to create parachutes that will glide down from a second-story stairwell, a lesson in aerodynamics. As the students manipulate masking tape and white paper, they make notes in their journals, looking like avid amateur scientists.


The scene is much the same in a third-grade classroom down the hall, where students appear deeply engaged as they create pulleys to move an object. Ditto a fifth-grade classroom, where you can hear the proverbial pin drop as students conduct experiments in submersion science, using marbles and beads.


The academic alchemy happening inside Bowden, a school where most kids come from low-income families, isn’t the result of luck or happenstance. About four years ago, it and two other public elementary schools on the East Side switched to a project-based model focused on science, technology, engineering and math, or STEM, to better prepare students for 21st century work.


The school changes were part of a larger plan over the last half-decade that pumped $54 million in federal grants into a relatively small area on the East Side, a place with some of the worst poverty rates in San Antonio and long-plagued by high crime, low-performing schools and little economic opportunity. In addition, the city ponied up more than $50 million in federal funds and bond money; the county supplied close to $3 million for a park project. Other money followed.


The goal was to apply a host of anti-poverty measures to the 3.5 square-mile area — the so-called “footprint” — to see if the lives of residents could be transformed.


As the grants draw to a close, officials are eager to provide numbers showing the effort has been a resounding success, pointing to gains like more children enrolled in early childhood education. And in that regard, the news seems wholly positive — more than half of children are now receiving formal early care, and programs are of higher quality.


But in the broader picture, the results are decidedly mixed. High school graduation rates remain low, as do student reading levels. College-readiness levels are substandard; school scores on standardized state tests have shown only short-term improvement. Families still move around a great deal during the school year, a practice that doesn’t bode well for children.


One other encouraging measure: Across a broader, 22-square-mile swath of the East Side, poverty has declined, dropping from 35 to 30.9 percent since 2010.


But in the neighborhoods where most of the action focused, the poverty rate has remained high and flat, fluctuating between 41 and 44 percent. In contrast, San Antonio’s poverty rate is 19.8 percent — a number that social scientists consider perilously high.


Officials say five years isn’t enough time to turn around neglect that has persisted for decades and that the true scope of the grants’ impact may not reveal itself for years. In the meantime, incremental progress matters, such as the sight of second-graders diligently bending over their science notebooks, immersed in their studies, preparing for a brighter future.


Buckets of money


The revitalization effort began in 2011 when the U.S. Department of Education awarded a $23.7 million Promise grant to the United Way of San Antonio and Bexar County to enact initiatives in the so-called Eastside Promise Neighborhood, a historically black but now Hispanic majority area that is home to some 18,000 residents.


The grant focused on education and social services. Five of the San Antonio Independent School District schools in the targeted area — one early education center, three elementary schools and a middle school — switched to a project-based, STEM curricula, shown to be particularly effective for students at low-income schools. In doing so, they followed the lead of nearby Sam Houston High School, which had adopted such a curriculum several years earlier. School officials brought in extra staff, hired reading specialists, ladled on support for teachers.


A plethora of resources for parents — adult literacy classes, nutrition seminars, parenting education workshops — were set up in schools and the wider community, as were adult education and workforce training programs, using funds from and partnerships with Alamo Colleges, Workforce Solutions Alamo, Goodwill Industries and other entities.


In addition to improving schools, footprint efforts included the creation of a “community school” at Wheatley Middle School that offers tutoring to kids, GED classes for adults and related services, as well as other grassroots social programs.


A year after the Promise grant was awarded, the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development gave a $29.7 million Choice grant to the San Antonio Housing Authority to tear down Wheatley Courts, a derelict, 1940s-era housing project smack dab in the footprint, and build in its place an amenities-rich, 215-unit “mixed-income” housing complex called East Meadows.


The apartment venture represents the latest iteration of how cities hope to use housing policy to fight segregation, by mixing low-income and middle- to high-income residents in the same development or neighborhood, the better to dilute concentrated poverty and the problems related to it — violent crime, drug addiction, broken families, poor health outcomes, underachievement.


Among major cities, San Antonio has one of the worst rates of concentrated poverty and income segregation in the country, a topic recently explored in Worlds Apart, a special report by the Express-News.


The first phase of East Meadows, scheduled to be done in May, will be followed by two more phases designed for seniors, disabled people and additional families. Altogether, more than 400 affordable housing units will be built in the area by 2019, at a total cost of $100 million, paid for with the Choice grant, other federal funds passed through the city, low-income housing tax credits and other sources.


Another infusion of federal money came in 2012 when the U.S. Department of Justice awarded two grants to reduce crime in the footprint, which has since been rebranded by the city as EastPoint: a $600,000 Byrne Criminal Justice Innovation grant for the Choice neighborhood and a $320,000 Byrne Public Safety Enhancement grant for the Promise neighborhood.


Altogether, the overlapping grants sought to address poverty at its roots, in effect turning one small sector of the city into a living laboratory for almost every urban poverty-fighting scheme imaginable.


In 2014, President Obama designated a 22-square-mile area on the East Side as a Promise Zone, one of a handful of “distressed communities” across the nation where leaders were already working to fight poverty. The 10-year designation, which geographically includes EastPoint, brought no money but gave organizations an edge when applying for federal funds.


Thanks to that help, nonprofits have snagged $17.4 million in federal funding for Promise Zone initiatives, such as the George Gervin Youth Center, which won a $1.1 million grant from the U.S. Department of Labor to provide education and work training to youth who’ve dropped out of school, aged out of foster care or spent time in the juvenile justice system.


The city provided $20 million in federal block grant funds to prepare the site for East Meadows, for street and infrastructure improvements in the surrounding neighborhood and “housing gap” financing. It provided another $45 million in 2012 bond and $6 million in street maintenance funds for drainage, parks, streets and sidewalks improvements throughout the larger Promise Zone.


Spurred by a red-hot gentrification craze in several neighborhoods within and around the footprint, private developers have poured more than $200 million into building upscale condos and rehabbing quaint, Victorian-style homes and stately mansions, said Mike Etienne, who directs the EastPoint office.


While shabby homes, sagging fences and urban blight still predominate, EastPoint is undeniably an area undergoing transformation. Vacant houses are being demolished, streets are being fixed. Gardens and parks have been created or are under way. Homeowners are getting help to fix their aging properties; new single-family homes are being built.


Almost 80 businesses in the larger Promise Zone have received grants to improve their storefront facades, at a cost of more than $800,000; more than 250 businesses have sprung up in the footprint ZIP codes — 78208, 78202 and 78203 — since 2011, according to city certificate-of-occupancy data.


Other money has flowed in. An $8.1 million health clinic is in the works. A $10 million Menger Creek Drainage and Linear Park project — think green spaces, outdoor pavilion, covered basketball court — will serve as a “destination point” on the East Side, Etienne said. Paid for with $6.5 million from the 2012 city bond and $2.8 million from Bexar County flood control funds, the project is under way and should be completed by summer, he said.


A developer recently announced plans for a $150 million mixed-use project in Denver Heights, a gentrifying neighborhood just south of the Alamodome, that will turn a former pallet manufacturing site into office space, retail, residences and a food hall.


Tony Leverett, the United Way official who directed Promise grant programs, said turning around decades of entrenched poverty is not an overnight job, no matter how much money you have.


“When you plant a seed, you don’t see the fruit right away,” he said. “We’ve planted seeds that are germinating and growing. We have to continue to be patient, and to have faith.”


A consulting firm hired by the city just completed an evaluation of the initiatives, citing wins and remaining challenges. A sustainability committee appointed by Mayor Ivy Taylor will use the report to examine what has worked, what hasn’t and whether any successes can be replicated in other areas of deep poverty in the city. That second report is due out this summer.


Some school administrators say they’re worried the money and help they’ve received through the Promise grant, such as extra staff, will end, leaving them in much the same situation as before. Others fear the Promise Zone’s momentum will eventually fizzle and go bust, as have so many urban renewal plans in the past, both here and across the nation. What impact the Trump administration, with its apparent antipathy toward programs for the poor, may have on grand antipoverty gestures such as the Promise Zone is anyone’s guess.


And as with any large bureaucratic undertaking — especially one with millions attached — there are critics who say things should have been done differently.


A focus on early education


It all started with panic. Several public schools on the East Side were slated to close in 2009 due to declining enrollment, as residents who could over the years fled to more affluent environs. To halt the exodus, then-Mayor Julián Castro and then-District 2 City Councilwoman Ivy Taylor convened a series of “reinvestment summits,” where solutions could be discussed and residents could vent their concerns to civic leaders.


Their concerns were legion — piled-up trash, stray dogs, spotty code enforcement, a sense that the city had utterly abandoned the East Side. Residents had a right to be skeptical that the summits would come to any good: Previous promises to bring prosperity to their world — new sports stadiums, snazzy entertainment developments — had fallen flat.


But this time was going to be different, according to officials. The United Way applied for and got a planning grant to be in the running for the Promise grant. A flurry of meetings ensued: work groups, public forums, home visits. A researcher compiled and analyzed data going back years. What they found was insufficiency clotting every aspect of East Side life: Overwhelmed parents. Stressed schools. Lack of safe housing. Little health care. Deficient transportation. Unhealthy food. Nonprofits stuck in silos.


Subcommittees were formed to address particular areas of concern, groups that included experts and nonprofit officials as well as residents. Early on, it was decided early childhood education had to be a focus.


“There was very little prekindergarten and quality early childhood education in the neighborhood,” said Mary Ellen Burns, senior vice president of grant implementation for the United Way. “We saw that if children didn’t receive that early help, by third or fourth grade they were having trouble and by sixth grade they were dropping out.”


The neighborhood had three nonprofit child care centers, serving children ages 5 and under, as well as a Head Start program at an SAISD public early childhood education center — Tynan — and prekindergarten at two of the three footprint elementary schools, Pershing and Bowden. (Prekindergarten and Head Start serves kids ages 3 to 4.) But there weren’t enough slots in the schools, and the centers lacked the resources to provide high-quality programs, Burns said.


In any case, the majority of young children were kept in informal care — babysat by friends, relatives — and not necessarily receiving the kind of input a growing brain needs.


Using grant funds, the United Way, working with SAISD, set about increasing both the quality of education and number of subsidized slots at the centers, expanded prekindergarten to the centers and, eventually, a third elementary school, Washington. Curricula were improved and standardized, as were methods used to track children’s progress. A local bank funded efforts to improve the training of center workers.


And starting in 2012, the Annie E. Casey Foundation gave small grants to the United Way to launch a partnership to create the so-called Dual Generation initiative at the existing early childhood education centers, culminating in a $1 million per year, seven-year grant in 2015.


“Dual Gen” provides low or no-cost high-quality, all-day early childhood education and after-school care to children ages 10 and under, while simultaneously providing parents with free adult education and workforce training, mostly at a new training center — called the Eastside Education & Training Center, or EETC — but at other sites as well, including St. Philip’s College.


“The idea is to help the whole family,” said Burns. The grant is renewable at the end of seven years.


In February 2015, the city received a five-year $7 million federal grant to institute free Early Head Start programs at six local child care centers, two of them in the footprint, another boost to quality of care, said Burns.


Statistics paint a success. At the “baseline” year of 2013, only about 26 percent of children 5 and under in the footprint were enrolled in formal early child care in any form. By last year, the final year of the grant, that number had risen to more than half, or 940 eligible children out of 1,865. Tynan and the three centers are now at capacity or near-capacity. One center, Healy-Murphy, has received a coveted accreditation status; the other two are on track to do so.


These numbers, in turn, have birthed other happy statistics.


Before the grant, almost 70 percent of children in the footprint entered kindergarten without the necessary skills. By 2015, 48 percent of 3-year-olds enrolled in Early Head Start in the footprint were found to be developmentally on track. And 41 percent of children in the public kindergarten classes were found to be “kinder-ready,” according to a test that measures children’s ability to meet developmental milestones across five areas upon school enrollment.


But like with much of the data, these numbers are qualified. Over the same period, the percentage of children in informal child care grew even more, from about 21 percent to 47.8 percent in the neighborhood. (The actual number is likely much higher, since the neighborhood questionnaire defined “informal care” as homes caring for three or more children.)


“It would be fair to say more people are caring for more children in an informal setting than four years ago,” Burns said. “This remains a challenge, because the link between formal early care and later academic success is clear.”


However, she added, Eastside Promise Neighborhood officials, realizing that informal care is “highly valued” in the community, created family support groups to assist informal caregivers. She couldn’t provide data on whether those supports were increasing kinder-readiness among informally cared-for children because “it’s too early in the process for that. We didn’t kick (the program) off until one year ago.”


Regarding Dual Gen, it’s not just the kids who benefit. Burns said. Of the 121 parents in the program last year, 49 found full-time work and 85 completed a certificate program or a semester of school. The goal is to place parents into “high-demand” jobs, she said. Recent graduates have found work as heavy equipment operators, medical assistants and commercial drivers.


Tiffane Garza, 28, whose mother grew up in Wheatley Courts, was one of them. Last fall, she’d temporarily moved with her four kids from the East Side to a subsidized West Side duplex, because of problems with her apartment. But her goal was to move back to the East Side, into the upscale-looking East Meadows sometime in the future.


Even though the single mother technically wasn’t living on the East Side, her kids were still gaining from EastPoint initiatives: Two children were reaping STEM benefits at Bowden; two more, ages 1 and 2, were enrolled at Healy-Murphy.


Through Dual Gen, Garza found a part-time job at an apartment leasing office. That success has motivated her to enroll in cosmetology school.


“I thought I was never going to be able to get on my feet, to have work,” she said, tears sliding down her face. “I don’t want the help to stop. My kids are happy. I’m happy. It’s a blessing.”


Her children come home from Healy-Murphy bearing worksheets; already they know their numbers and colors, she said proudly.


United Way officials said efforts are under way to identify funding for the early childhood education programs, in the event the Dual Gen and Early Head Start grants aren’t renewed. What’s more, middle- and high-income “private pay” families drawn to an ever-revitalizing East Side will also help keep the centers financially afloat, they said.


Statistics show challenges remain


When it comes to middle school and high school, EastPoint data reveal a concerning picture. Rates of chronic absenteeism among students at Wheatley Middle School rose stunningly into the double-digits from the 2014-2015 school year to the 2015-2016 school year. In grades 7 and 8, for example, the rate ballooned from around 6 to 8 percent to almost 30 percent.


In that same time period, more than one-third of Sam Houston High School freshmen were chronically absent, with a rate that rose from 33.2 percent to 34.6 percent, according to statistics provided by the United Way.


Burns attributed the rise at Wheatley to a number of factors — a change in school leadership, the lack of a full-time attendance clerk, an increase in housing instability among families who’d lost their homes when Wheatley Courts was demolished over a six-month period starting in 2014.

GRAPHIC: A mixed bag of statistics

As for the high school, freshman year “is the tough transition year and chronic absenteeism is the highest,” Burns said. The numbers increased despite the fact Promise grant funds were used to bring in City Year AmeriCorps members in 2012 to work specifically with middle and high school students at risk of chronic truancy.


Districts also keep track of their “mobility” rates — the percentage of students who leave or switch campuses or districts during the school year — because it’s a good indicator of how stable or unstable their lives are.


Studies show high mobility can cause students to have lower attendance and achievement scores; highly mobile students are twice as likely to repeat a grade and half as likely to graduate from high school as their non-mobile peers.


Officials had hoped mobility rates in the footprint would greatly decline. In the 2012-2013 school year, the average rate across the schools was 33.3 percent — higher than SAISD’s rate of 25 percent, and much higher than the 18 percent of a comparatively affluent district like Northside ISD.


Over the course of the grant, little progress was observed, with mobility rates staying basically flat, except for minor overall fluctuations.


Burns offered reasons why the rate has proved so stubborn, acknowledging they’re “anecdotal,” with no data to back them up. As children benefit and grow because of anti-poverty initiatives, she said, families may decide to move to better neighborhoods and schools. Similarly, as parents gain training and employment, they may decide to move closer to jobs elsewhere.


The demolition of Wheatley Courts also caused environmental hazards that made it necessary for some of the 205 families living in the courts to leave the footprint to find new housing. Some of the high mobility rate is also undoubtedly linked to “economic instability,” such as families being evicted by landlords, she added.

GRAPHIC: East Side poverty rates

Christine Drennon, associate professor of sociology and anthropology at Trinity University, who did the planning research for the Promise grant, said she’s not surprised mobility rates didn’t improve because the grant programs’ focus was misplaced. From the start, she lobbied to spend more money on parent rooms, rather than on early childhood education.


“One of the big findings (of her research) was that mobility is a serious problem,” she said. “We were able to show the impact it has on grades. But (the United Way and others) didn’t even try to put effort there. They didn’t even try to address the mobility issue.”


Parent rooms provide parents with a range of support, such as workshops, educational enrichment and referrals to emergency assistance and job training. Parent room volunteers conduct door-to-door home visits to find out how kids are doing in school. The whole point of the parent room is to connect the family to the school, and parents to each other. Perhaps most vitally, Drennon said, the rooms are “safe spaces” where parents, often not high school graduates themselves, become comfortable in the school environment, which in turn empowers them to support their kids and create a learning environment at home.


Parent rooms were already in place in the footprint schools before the grant programs started; beefing them up would have helped families form a stronger attachment to their schools, prompting them to stay in place and not disrupt their children’s lives, Drennon said.


The Promise grant was “an invitation for a revolution,” she said.


“I thought we were going to blow stuff up, then find the best models for inner-city education, get the best minds in the country together,” she said. “That wasn’t done. There were no new faces on that team.”


Burns said data and feedback gleaned in the planning process showed early education was the direst need. She added that the United Way spends $1.8 million annually in parent rooms at 28 schools in the city, roughly $386,000 for the six parent rooms in footprint schools. As part of the grant, the agency also created a volunteer parent-advocate position to serve as an adviser on teams that help at-risk students at Wheatley and Sam Houston.


Officials were also hoping to see strides in school state testing scores. The footprint schools were tasked to reach annual “performance targets” set by the grant. These target scores on the state standardized STAAR test in reading and math were below average state levels but still represented improvement, given that the campuses historically were performing 10 to 22 percentage points below the district scores. During the first three years, the schools met the targets — with some even earning academic achievement notices — but then the scores plateaued or dropped in the fourth year.


Judy Ratlief, director of operations for EPN and longtime educator on the East Side, attributed the lagging school performances to increasing rigor in state testing.


“Across the board there was a district-wide drop,” in scores, she said. “These particular schools were not out of the norm.” However, the footprint declines were for the most part steeper than the district drop, which, as far as reading and math scores for fifth- and eighth-graders, was among the lowest in Bexar County.


Even with the decline, all of the footprint schools met state standards last year, except for Wheatley, which scored “improvement required,” as it has in the past.

GRAPHIC: Promise Zone budget

Regarding the Promise benchmarks, Wheatley posted the most disappointing showing, Burns said. Part of the problem may lie in the middle school paradigm itself, she said. Starting next year, Wheatley will become home to the Young Men’s Leadership Academy, serving boys in grades 4 through 8. The footprint elementary schools will gradually phase in grades to create a prekindergarten-8th grade model. The move to dismantle middle schools is occurring across the district, given evidence showing students tend to fare better staying at their elementary school, Burns said.


Despite the lagging test numbers, the switch to a STEM-focused-curriculum has been deemed so successful, say grant administrators, that the three elementary schools have begun the process to apply to become in-district STEM charter schools, and SAISD plans to implement aspects of the program district-wide.


Helping an iconic high school


Some school administrators worry that progress gained might be lost. Case in point: A partnership between the Eastside Promise Neighborhood, Trinity University, SAISD and the Ewing Halsell Foundation that enabled that small fleet of reading teachers, instructional deans, peer-assistant teachers and other support staff to be deployed into footprint schools has reached its end.


Next year, they’ll be replaced by “implementation specialists” — one staff person per footprint school who will provide coaching and mentoring to teachers, paid for by SAISD.


Darnell White, in his eighth year as principal at Sam Houston, isn’t sure that will be enough. But he does know he’s witnessed a new energy within the halls of the iconic school, progress he attributes largely to the Promise grant, with its influx of support staff and other measures.


The school, once shedding students, has seen enrollment jump from 850 to 1,130 since the grant began. Groups like ROTC, band, engineering club and academic decathlon enjoy robust membership and compete at state and national levels, White said. More students are opting to enroll in college or post-secondary education — 45.8 percent in 2014, versus 44.5 percent in 2013, according to Sam Houston data.


Some of this increase may relate to the fact that Sam Houston gained an engineering magnet program several years before the grant began — magnet programs tend to draw a more motivated set of students and parents, experts say. (This year, about 8 percent of students hail from outside the footprint; Sam Houston is also a traditional high school with students on a non-magnet track.) In fact, it was the high school’s embrace of a STEM-related curricula that prompted Promise grant officials to switch the “feeder” elementary schools and Tynan to a STEM-focused format, so that students might be better prepared once they reached Sam Houston.


Last year, SAISD redesigned its high school magnets to closely align with Alamo Colleges’ programs, said Leslie Price, spokeswoman for the district. Since 2010, some Sam Houston students follow a New Tech “school within a school” model that allows students to earn college credits while in high school.


Promise Zone boosters like to point to Sam Houston’s vastly improved graduation rate as an indication of the federal grant’s impact, but the rise actually began before grant programs started, leaping dramatically in one year, from 57.1 percent in 2010 to 81.1 percent in 2011.


Price attributes some of that significant jump to a host of efforts that have been implemented across the district to keep students in school, such as interventions with at-risk students and a credit recovery course.


But part of that rise likely owed to a new law that in 2011 began letting districts exclude certain populations of students from drop-out and graduation tallies. Without that policy change, Sam Houston’s 2011 graduation rate would have been 10.4 points lower — 70.7 percent, Price said.


Other factors that may have played a role in upping Sam Houston’s graduation rate include the creation of so-called individual graduation committees during the 2014-2015 school year, which allow students who’ve failed one or two required state tests during their tenure in high school to nonetheless graduate, if their coursework, attendance or other variables are deemed adequate.


The Sam Houston graduation rate last year was 82.2 percent.


Many in the neighborhood credit the success at Sam Houston to White himself, a dynamic leader by all accounts and a towering presence as he strides the halls of the school.


But even with all the changes and improvements, White said too many Sam Houston students still read below grade level — 65 percent, according to district data. Last year, only 7 percent of graduates were deemed college ready in reading and math, down from 24 percent the year before. (Schools across the city likewise saw their numbers drop, due to a change in how the Texas Education Agency calculates college readiness, from scores on a state test to the TSIA, a college entrance exam.)


Promise grant administrators don’t track college-readiness, Burns said, focusing instead on the percent of Sam Houston graduates who are able to start their first year of college without having to take remedial courses — classes students must take to improve their skills in math and reading before moving on to college classes.


Before the grant began, 22.1 percent of graduates required no remediation; by the class of 2014, that number had improved to 30.5 percent. But by the class of 2015, the number was down to 20.6 percent — almost as low as when the programs started.


Burns said the cohort of students in the 2015 school year entered high school further behind academically than most and never caught up, even with “intensive interventions.” Changes have since been put in place that seek to intervene earlier, she said.


On a more positive note, a healthy percentage of Sam Houston students — 65 percent — were deemed “college and career ready,” a less stringent category that includes graduates who demonstrate preparedness by earning credits in at least two advanced/dual-credit courses as juniors or seniors or who complete a four-year plan of study in career or technical education while in high school. In this category, the graduates nip at the heels of more affluent students in Northside ISD, where 71 percent were deemed college and career ready.


No matter how you slice the statistics, White’s optimism remains strong.


“What the Eastside Promise Neighborhood was able to do was provide exposure — not only to expose students to the outside world, through competitions and the like, but to expose the community and larger city to the success going on at Sam Houston,” he said.


It simply may be too soon to judge the true results of the grant, White said, echoing others. All those kids who at this moment are enrolled in high-quality early childhood education, soaking up all that intellectual stimulation? Who knows what impact they’ll have once they bubble up through the system, he wondered.


One thing White knows for sure about his school.


“It’s never going to go back to the way it was,” he said, “not as long as I’m here.”


Next: Choosing the Choice neighborhood


mstoeltje@express-news.net

project.twitter_text: Promises to Keep: Have federal #grants  on a #neglected side of town made any progress? By Melissa Fletcher Stoeltje

project.subtitle: Families scour Mexico looking for 70,000 lost children
project.byline: Story by Aaron Nelsen | Photos by Julysa Sosa
project.title: A search for life on roads of death
project.byline_picker: {"authors":[{"id":"custom","profile_name":"Story by Aaron Nelsen | Photos by Julysa Sosa","has_avatar":false,"is_atavist":false,"url":null,"type":"custom"}],"publication":{"id":"user-123027","profile_name":"San Antonio Express-News","avatar":"https://atavist.com/data/files/organization/61567/image/derivative/cropandscale~150x150~12313971101-1463076263-82.jpg","is_publication":false,"type":"user","url":"http://projects.expressnews.com","is_atavist":true,"has_avatar":true}}

sections.title: Portraits of the travelers

sections.body:
HUIXTLA, Mexico — María Mercedes Lemus raised her daughter the old-fashioned way, rooted in family and faith. Yet late one December night, the 60-year-old Honduran found herself standing in the greasy yellow light of a brothel entrance in southern Mexico, praying that her daughter was inside.


Ana Victoria Lemus had set out for the United States in March 2010 at age 17, chasing the promise of a life better than the one she had in Honduras. She phoned her mother from the northern Mexican border city of Reynosa, saying she was to be smuggled into Texas the next day.


Then she vanished.


While many Central American parents are left to wonder what has become of their disappeared loved ones, Lemus could not let it go. She uncovered a few leads, but nothing came of them.


In desperation, she joined the XII Caravana de Madres Centroamericanas, a group of mostly mothers who make an annual trek through Mexico on a seemingly impossible mission: looking for the missing.


It was another woman in the caravan, following a lead for her own relative, who had unexpectedly run across signs of Lemus’ daughter.


On a sweltering night earlier this month, more than 1,000 miles from where she’d last heard from her daughter, Lemus stood in a red-light district, wearing a laminated photo of Ana Victoria around her neck. Drunken men pointed at the image, offering lewd comments rather than leads. A couple of prostitutes said they recognized the girl, though they knew her by a different name, and said she was working in a guarded brothel.


Just outside, a man with two young women at his side strolled past Lemus, a bodyguard missing an eye following closely behind them. Lemus steeled herself, and asked to be let in.


“If you go in, you aren’t coming out,” the doorman warned her and three others accompanying Lemus that night.


“We all felt the danger,” Lemus said, explaining why she and her small group had little choice but to turn back. Yet the disappointment was tempered by renewed hope, however tenuous.


The caravan’s heart-wrenching journey is such that the mere prospect of finding a daughter as a possible victim of sex trafficking is seen as one of the few highlights after three weeks on the road, searching across more than 3,000 miles of Mexico.


By most estimates, at least 70,000 Central American migrants have been forcibly disappeared in Mexico over the past decade. Others say the number of disappeared is well above 100,000, but no one knows for certain.


Migrants’ undocumented status, and the routes they navigate through hotly contested drug-trafficking corridors, make them an easy, and profitable, target for kidnapping and extortion.


The situation has deteriorated since the start of Mexico’s Southern Border Plan in late 2014. Pressured by the United States to stem the tide of migrants fleeing the violence-plagued Northern Triangle of El Salvador, Honduras and Guatemala, immigration officials pinched off well-trodden routes, pushing vulnerable people further into the shadows.


Mexico now apprehends more Central Americans than the United States — 190,000 in Mexico compared to 117,000 in the U.S. from October 2015 to September 2016 — which critics say has largely exported the refugee crisis to its neighbor. In spite of the crackdown, the exodus of desperate people casting their lot with smugglers continues unabated. Many migrant communities fear conditions will worsen under President-elect Donald Trump.


In this increasingly hostile environment, the mothers’ caravan, which this year included a few fathers, sisters and brothers, scoured prisons and brothels and applied pressure to law enforcement and politicians in an effort to call attention to their missing family members.


David Alexander Jarquin Pineda disappeared in Reynosa. Jarvin Josue Velásquez Lacayo last was seen in Piedras Negras. And in July 2013, Gilver Josue Alvares walked into the yawning desert between Sonora and Arizona.


None has been heard from since.


Gilver was a skinny 14-year-old with migrant dreams. He promised his mother he wouldn’t do anything rash, like follow his cousins out of Honduras, but he longed for the triumphant spoils that are the domain of emigrants. He imagined himself in a shiny pickup, and providing a home for his hard-working mother.


Impulse got the better of him as his cousins walked out the door while his mother was at work, and Gilver raced to join them.


“He left without saying goodbye,” his mother, Nohemy Yamileth Alvares, recalled sullenly. “He was so small.”


Last contact in the desert


Alvares was raising Gilver and his older brother, Darwin, on her own, struggling to make the $50 she earned cooking for well-to-do families in the capital of Tegucigalpa stretch to the end of the month.


When Gilver called to say he was with his cousins, Gustavo and Pedro Luís, they assured their aunt they would look out for him. She kept tabs on them via Facebook. Their last conversation came from Caborca, Sonora, a notorious staging point where immigrants make arrangements with smugglers to traverse the unforgiving desert into Arizona.


Later, Gustavo would tell his aunt that they had been walking in the desert for four days. He said he and Pedro Luís left Gilver with the smuggler to search for water. When they heard trucks approaching, they instinctively ducked for cover. By the time they returned, Gilver and the smuggler were gone.


Alvares, 41, has downcast eyes and wears her hair pulled back tightly in a bun. In late November, she and another caravan member, Liliam Hortensia Morales Jovel, a soft-spoken 50-year-old Salvadoran searching for her younger sister, Jacqueline, broke away from the caravan to search for clues on the Mexico-Arizona border.


Neither had come so close to the ground where Gilver and Jacqueline had vanished. Alvares had not expected to make the trip at all. After the Honduran organization extended an invitation to join the caravan, she decided God must have something in store for her.


Alvares often was contemplative during the journey, consumed by sorrow and regret.


“I was at the point of falling into depression,” Alvares said. “Sometimes I just think of him and I cry.”


A disturbing phenomenon


Desperate Central American mothers began venturing into Mexico years ago to look for their missing sons and daughters. Eventually, families of the disappeared organized in El Salvador, Honduras, Guatemala and Nicaragua.


A dozen years ago, activist Marta Sánchez Soler of Mexico co-founded the Mesoamerica Migrant Movement, which organizes the annual caravan. This year’s edition adopted the maxim, “We look for life on roads of death.”


In the early days, the grassroots social movement toiled in relative obscurity, and at no small risk to its members. Then in 2010, a bedraggled Ecuadoran immigrant stumbled into a military checkpoint in the northern Mexican border state of Tamaulipas.


Through parched lips, the man spoke of horrors on a remote ranch near the town of San Fernando. There marines found the decomposing remains of 72 Central and South American immigrants who were executed for refusing to join the Zetas, a savage drug cartel operating with near total impunity in the region.


Through this chance encounter, a nation awoke to a disturbing phenomenon. The following year, 193 more migrants were unearthed in dozens of mass graves across Tamaulipas, and still more were discovered in Nuevo León in 2012.


In a nation facing its own epidemic of disappearances, Mexico’s National Registry of Disappeared and Missing Persons has registered just a couple of hundred cases of disappeared migrants. Meanwhile, the National Human Rights Commission reports the incidence of migrant kidnappings has soared into the tens of thousands.


“The majority of disappeared cases over the last 10 years were completely forced,” said Rubén Figueroa, who grew up in Tabasco, an activist with the movement and investigator of disappeared migrants. “Many of them are probably dead.”


This stark reality hasn’t kept Figueroa from searching.


Ahead of each caravan, organizers pore over official documents, photos and letters, and they meticulously interview family members, anything that might give rise to a lead. Over the past several years, Figueroa, a former migrant, has been at this chaotic epicenter.


At age 16, Figueroa packed his birth certificate and joined migrants headed north. He made it across the border into Texas on his third attempt, eventually settling in North Carolina.


Over the next six years, he worked in factory and construction jobs. The experience awakened in Figueroa a profound sense of injustice, pulling him inexorably back to his roots and the migrant trail.


One day while back home in the tropics of Tabasco in southern Mexico, Figueroa’s eyes welled with tears as he gazed upon dozens of migrants riding atop a northbound train. He made up his mind then to do something.


Figueroa now is 34 and thickset with a swirl of dark hair. He made a name for himself tracking smugglers by their distinctive tattoos and scars, or colorful nicknames. They learned how smugglers reeled in unsuspecting migrants, and they believed they were making a difference. But everything comes at a price.


Word had come down the Zetas were looking to kill Figueroa and his mother. Figueroa skipped town for a few days until things calmed down. In his view, in spite of the sacrifices he and other activists have made, migrants are more exposed than ever.


“There is a policy of repression, of militarization, that’s why people die, not just because the border is dangerous,” Figueroa said. “The authorities can say that traffickers do these things, but the policies of migration force immigrants into their hands.”


Raising awareness


Another member of this year’s caravan was Walter Omar Jarquin Roque, 49, a square-jawed father of three from El Salvador. He also took a side trip from the caravan’s main route, looking for his son, David Jarquin Pineda, amid the industrial sprawl of Reynosa.


In 2014, Jarquin’s son had scraped together a few hundred dollars, and his father had pitched in the rest, selling his house, Jeep Cherokee and a revolver to help the 23-year-old chase his version of the American dream. Jarquin gave his son his best advice and put him in God’s hands.


David called the evening before he was to cross the Rio Grande. It was a moment they had prepared for.


“He said everything was OK,” Jarquin recalled.


Two and a half years have come and gone without word from David. After he disappeared, Jarquin received extortion attempts, but the former police officer sniffed out the scams. Dark thoughts colonized his mind. Is his son being tortured, is he in prison?


“The pain is something you learn to survive,” Jarquin said. “If we never find each other, that pain will always be there.”


Jarquin quickly gained a reputation for being plain-spoken about migrant rights. Privately, he confessed that each time he opened his heart, he believed it narrowed the distance between him and his son.


Nearing the end of November, Jarquin and two mothers, led by Figueroa, filed complaints with the attorney general’s office in Reynosa. It was a first in a city long thought to be under the corrupting influence of organized crime.


“What they do with the information is another matter,” Figueroa said. “Perhaps they don’t know the reality, or maybe they’re indifferent. We have to wake them up, and above all pressure them to follow through on their promises of an official search.”


The caravan movement largely is about bringing visibility to the disappeared. In towns frequented by migrants, the families marched through city streets, chanting slogans: “Listen, son, your mother is in the fight,” and “They were taken alive, and we want them alive,” usually in the presence of the very immigration officials and state police so frequently suspected of mistreating migrants.


In the state of Tabasco, the families faced down state officials, who eagerly pledged to look out for migrant rights, while in the neighboring state of Chiapas, immigration authorities agreed to provide information on migrants who may be held in local prisons.


Mexico’s attorney general’s office has established two units to investigate crimes against migrants and cases of the disappeared, known simply as the Unit and the Mechanism.


Leonor de Jesús Figueroa Jácome heads up the unit. She touted successfully breaking up rings of kidnappers, but acknowledged that significant challenges remain. Her office has registered barely 120 complaints.


“Many legal departments operate in isolation, and they don’t share information, or they don’t upload it to the attorney general’s office,” Figueroa Jácome said.


Complaints of abuse


Advocates say greater visibility means little in the face of tough immigration enforcement. It wasn’t long after the Southern Border Plan took effect that immigration officials began sweeping up migrants by the thousands.


The U.S. State Department funneled $70 million of its Mérida Initiative assistance during the 2014 and 2015 fiscal years, earmarked for inspection equipment and canine teams, with tens of millions in additional funding requested for continued operations on Mexico’s southern border.


In October 2014, a new shelter opened in Chahuites, Oaxaca: the Centro de Ayuda Humanitaria a Migrantes.


Between 2014 and 2015, the shelter workers filed 900 cases of abuse with state authorities. In 2016, the number of formal complaints has grown to more than 1,000.


Despite the staggering number of complaints, Jéssica Cárdenas Canuto, the coordinator of the Chauites shelter, says it should come as no surprise that little has come of their efforts. Among the more frequent complaints by migrants is that of bribes paid to Mexican officials. Earlier this year, around two dozen police officers in a neighboring community were arrested in October for kidnapping migrants.


“Despite the high number of complaints since the Southern Border Plan started, not one person has been detained,” Cárdenas said. “It’s very suspicious that in all of this time, two years, the public prosecutor’s office hasn’t found anyone.”


‘Bridges of Hope’


Not everyone is forcibly disappeared. Some choose to disappear out of shame or circumstance, but some long to reconnect.


Seven years had passed since Juana del Carmen Amaya’s husband forced her to sever communication with her mother in El Salvador. But when the caravan was in Chahuites, Oaxaca, last year, where Amaya, 29, now was living, she was able to get a local priest to reach out to the caravan leaders for her while her husband was away.


Figueroa tracked down Amaya’s mother, and a reunion was arranged for this year. Near the end of the caravan, the mother and daughter met in a tearful embrace. Reyna Amaya, 45, met the two grandsons who she’d never known, and her contrite son-in-law.


The movement calls these reunions “Bridges of Hope” and there have been 269 over the years. They are meant to give the others hope. Realistically, however, most of the families on the caravan face the grim reality that they will never know what has become of their disappeared.


One afternoon Alvares found herself staring out over the border. Darwin had warned her of the ugly things that visited migrants in the desert, yet seeing a group of migrants huddle under a tree for shade, preparing to cross the international line, Alvares’ eyes welled up with tears.


“I imagined my sons,” Alvares said. “I imagined them on the run through the hills, hiding.”


The caravan tested the emotional stamina of its members. It was a roller coaster of laughter and camaraderie, sorrow and introspection. Morales scribbled poetry on a folded sheet of paper. She found beauty and pain in an old woman resting her tired feet on the railroad tracks. And in the throngs of strange faces, she searched for Jaqueline.


There was José Ricardo Ramos, 76, known to all as grandpa, who danced to the beat of cumbia to everyone’s delight. And María Loria Cabrera, 64, who sang an uneven, yet apropos rendition of “Cansada del Camino,” or Tired of the Road.


María Lemus kept a journal, musing on Mexico’s variegated countryside. Its splendor masquerading the turbulent undercurrent of migration. Angela Lacayo Alfaro celebrated her 46th birthday on the bus. As the honeyed sound of Las Mañanitas floated through the bus, the sentimental Honduran mother held a photo of her son, Jarvin, who vanished in Piedras Negras earlier this year, and cried.


“We’re almost at the end and I don’t have a single lead on my son,” she lamented. “But I feel that I’ve left behind a seed. Someone has to have seen his photo, soon that seed will bear fruit.”


The caravan had brought Alvares closer to her son, and yet somehow he felt further away. The prospect of returning home to an empty house was almost more than she could bear.


“I woke up last night thinking of him,” she said, standing near the banks of the Suchiate River, which demarcates the international line with Guatemala. “I’m going home sad.”


anelsen@express-news.net


Twitter: @amnelsen
